Award.AwardTitle: Design of High Temperature Shape Memory Alloys

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a recent, significant interest in high temperature shape memory alloy capabilities that will broaden the utilization of these materials. Shape memory alloys are unique in their ability to return to their original shape after deformation. The research emphasis of this proposal is on the development of new high temperature shape memory alloys with capabilities above 400 degree Celsius. The crystallography and the atomic displacements leading to the creation of twins, a rearrangement of the atoms, will be investigated via meso-scale modeling. The compositions will be optimized to control the strengths of secondary phases within the material and hence the reversibility of the phase transformations which dictate the material behavior. The research will also hone in on the processing of these materials for sample preparation, including polycrystals and single crystals. The investigation will include experiments to measure the behavior during loading and unloading and heating and cooling under stress in order to develop high temperature resistance for several potential compositions of nickel, titanium, cobalt and iron based shape memory materials with ternary additions. The proposed measurements of local displacements and strains will provide a critical check on the atomic deformation planes and the predicted stress at the onset of twinning in these materials. These measurements will be made with digital image correlation techniques, which will also be advanced during this research.

The expected benefit of the research is to establish multi-component shape memory alloys that can operate at higher temperatures with actuation capabilities that can benefit the aerospace and other high temperature industries. The aim is to develop high temperature alloys with shape memory functionality without compromising strength, ductility and durability. The scientific benefits of the research include a better understanding of the mechanical response based on the underlying composition, crystallography, and microstructure. The educational benefits of the research will be enhanced with the preparation of a monograph on shape memory and a series of lectures that combine atomistic calculations with mesoscopic theories. This will be an advancement in the pedagogical treatment of shape memory alloys elevating the materials science and continuum mechanics perspectives and understanding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is on high temperature shape memory alloys which are a unique class of metallic materials that can be used for sensing and actuation. The temperature capability of the most well-known shape memory material, NiTi, is limited to 100°C. In this study, we achieved operational temperatures exceeding 400°C, hence extending the potential utility of these materials. 

Intellectual Merit: In shape memory alloys (SMAs), the success in raising the transformation strain, transformation temperatures and slip resistance to levels above 12%, 250°C and 1GPa respectively has remained elusive. Achieving high strains in shape memory field are of utmost importance, this has to be accompanied with strong slip resistance to ensure functionality under temperature or strain cycling. We achieved high strains with NiTiHf alloys for the first time, accompanied with high transformation temperatures and high slip resistance. The present research resulted in extraordinarily high strains, exceeding 18% in tension for NiTiHf with 13.3 at.%Hf. In comparison, the most well-known shape memory alloy, NiTi, exhibits 10% strain. Transformation temperatures exceeding 400°C for NiTi25Hf alloy were achieved which are higher than previous results on NiTiX based alloys studied to-date. These findings of combined high strains and high temperatures (420°C) are unprecedented in the shape memory research field.

Broad Impacts: 

There are strong efforts in the SMA community to develop SMAs with high temperature capability. Our results have an impact on the advancement of our understanding with such high temperature alloys. The modeling efforts provide the energy of the crystal phases and the lattice constants (for example orthorhombic versus monoclinic martensites) hence the correct calculation of the transformation strains. The modeling efforts can also give us the resistance to slip (i.e. the flow stress for martensite) and the twinning stress (martensite). The impact will be not only on creating a fundamental understanding of the processes governing transformation characteristics, but ultimately to design the structure of such materials for higher reversibility at the atomic level and better performance in applications. An important finding is that with increasing Hf content, these alloys exhibit higher transformation strains and this increases the range of utility of these alloys. The fact that the experimental strains are lower than the theoretical values point to the difficulty in achieving a single variant as elucidated by extensive digital image correlation studies in our work. The digital image correlation at multiscales allows tracking the evolution of multiple martensite variants and provides a measure of the intrinsic transformation strains. The utility of the high resolution DIC we developed with stitching of data sets have broad implications. From the technological viewpoint, the impact of the research is in actuator applications at high temperatures, control of fluid-structure interactions, and potentially in elasto-caloric effects for refrigeration.


Last Modified: 11/14/2016
Modified by: Huseyin Sehitoglu
